34.fullDescription:
In the function `resetInvestment()` the following predictable state variables are used to determine Ether recipient:
- block.timestamp
34.name: OtherVulnerability

34.fullDescription:
In the function `resetInvestment()` a non-zero amount of Ether is sent to an address taken from storage slot 1.
There is a check on storage index 1. This storage slot can be written to by calling the function `resetInvestment()`.

There is a check on storage index 3. This storage slot can be written to by calling the function `resetInvestment()`.
34.name: AccessControlVulnerability

34.fullDescription: A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function resetInvestment(). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location
34.name: FrontRunningVulnerability

34.fullDescription: The return value of an external call is not checked. Note that execution continue even if the called contract throws.
34.name: UncheckedLowCallsVulnerability

35.fullDescription:
In the function `resetInvestment()` the following predictable state variables are used to determine Ether recipient:
- block.timestamp
35.name: OtherVulnerability

35.fullDescription: The return value of an external call is not checked. Note that execution continue even if the called contract throws.
35.name: UncheckedLowCallsVulnerability

35.fullDescription:
Governmental.resetInvestment (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#30-40) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- owner.send(this.balance - 1000000000000000000) (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#35)
35.name: AccessControlVulnerability

30.fullDescription:

	Dangerous calls:

30.name: AccessControlVulnerability

30.fullDescription:
Governmental.resetInvestment (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#30-40) uses timestamp for comparisons
	Dangerous comparisons:
	- block.timestamp < lastInvestmentTimestamp + ONE_MINUTE (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#31-32)
30.name: TimeManipulationVulnerability

31.fullDescription:
Governmental.resetInvestment (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#30-40) uses timestamp for comparisons
	Dangerous comparisons:

31.name: TimeManipulationVulnerability

fullDescription.text:
In the function `resetInvestment()` the following predictable state variables are used to determine Ether recipient:
- block.timestamp

In the function `resetInvestment()` a non-zero amount of Ether is sent to an address taken from storage slot 1.
There is a check on storage index 1. This storage slot can be written to by calling the function `resetInvestment()`.

There is a check on storage index 3. This storage slot can be written to by calling the function `resetInvestment()`.

Multiple sends exist in one transaction, try to isolate each external call into its own transaction. As external calls can fail accidentally or deliberately.
Consecutive calls: 
Call at address: 708
A possible transaction order independence vulnerability exists in function resetInvestment(). The value or direction of the call statement is determined from a tainted storage location
The return value of an external call is not checked. Note that execution continue even if the called contract throws.

Governmental.resetInvestment (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#30-40) sends eth to arbitrary user
	Dangerous calls:
	- owner.send(this.balance - 1000000000000000000) (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#35)

Governmental.resetInvestment (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#30-40) uses timestamp for comparisons
	Dangerous comparisons:
	- block.timestamp < lastInvestmentTimestamp + ONE_MINUTE (/data/demo_analysis/source_code/governmental_survey.sol#31-32)
